Cell.Data: "Enneracts resurface every now and then. Most lucky finders, not knowing better, will resell them to be siphoned into energy crystals that will fuel weapons or industries. Scholars have theorized that they may contain a small fragment of a divine entity's power, stored in an ancient but definitely manmade device. While mages may spend their life studying a few Enneracts to replicate their signature essence and cast spells, a select few people are however drawn to these, able to absorb the energy within and make it theirs in an instant."
Perform a basic attack with your equipped weapon.
Punch your foes like your life depends on it!
A Republican Instructor once told you: "So you're good at throwing punches eh? Great. Now pick-up a weapon or go home". Which was a little ironic given the military academy was your only home.
Performs a powerful Melee combo with your Shield and equipped weapon.
Slice, hack, or smash foes with your main hand weapon.
Humans' creativity knows no bounds when it comes to inventing tools of slaughter. The only thing that matches that inspiration, is their will to do it in a stylish and effective way.
Unleash a flurry of blows with both of your weapons.

Traditional fighters tend to only consider the shield as the superior option. Clearly they have never fought the Screaming Furies of Laibon: A regiment of women dual wielding kopeshes while shouting death away.
Swing your two handed sword to slash down your foes.

At the military academy your strategy teacher rambled times and times again about the battle of Samatras. The Kuei empire's light cavalry spotted a regiment of Republican footmen isolated from the rest of the battle. A swift sweep should have been enough to break the poor infantry... except they were greatsword wielders. That day, the Republican army had horsemeat for dinner.
Maul your enemies down with your two handed mace.

A jest only truly appreciated by battlehammer users: "Before a tournament, a knight spends two hours turtling behind three layers of thick fullplate armor. Scared of being late, he hurries in the arena and asks his unarmoured challenger "What time is it?", the lowborn picks up his maul and answers: "It's hammer time!".
Swing your two handed axe to cut down your foes.
Some see fighting as a dance, an art, a poetic vision of murder. Meanwhile, others wield a big fat greataxe and chop people in half as casually as a butcher cuts meat. To each their own.
Unleash a flurry of blows with two daggers.

Killers, murderers, sociopaths and assassins all seem to share an unhealthy fetish for knives. Some researshers tried to understand this phenomenon. Their endeavour did not yield any conclusive results given that half of them gave up after the first half got slaughtered, all with a similar cause of death: multiple stabbings.
Fire at your foes with a crystal pistol.
There's an old saying in the explorer's guild of Stormfall: "Do not bring a sword to a gunfight".
Fire at your foes with two crystal pistols.

In the independent city of Archion there used to be an academy to learn sophisticated fighting stances with two pistols. The training was so intense that people could be gone for years without being seen again. The world later learned that the academy got closed. Apparently its masters were hidding the bodies of an absurdly high amount of students dead to self-inflicted injuries.
Execute a deadly barrage of blows and shots.

After several drinks of liquor, Captain James, a skypirate known for his famous heist against the flying city of Archion, will often share his wisdom with the newbloods in his crew: "Alrigh' gather 'round ya silly skyvirgins! Listen to me y'all! Like oi always say, victory ain't 'bout the size of yar canons, nah it ain't, but tis all 'bout...", and that's generally when he passes out.
The great equalizer. A lord on his highhorse, a knight with a castleforged sword, or a pitchfork wielding peasant will all share the same fate once showered with arrows.
Tap into the staff's power to cast projectiles.
Charges into battle? Muddy skirmishes? Gory eviscerations? These are peasants practices at best. Exterminating your foes from afar with magic is just more stylish... and cleaner.
Let loose a volley of arrows on a circular area, damaging enemies over time as long as they remain in it.\n\nOnly usable with bows and pistols.
HephaÃ¤ron the Maestre of industry forged "Krearion, The First Bow" so that men could master the art of raining death.
Throw a spinning dualblade in a front line, damaging those caught in its path.\n\nAttack : Only usable with daggers, bows and pistols.

HephaÃ¤ron, Primordial of Industry, forged "Omeagram,The First Double Bladed Sword", to push humans to their limits in terms of grace and agility. Manipulating this weapon can be as deadly for its wielder as it is for its foes.
Summon a colossal hammer and bring it down on your foes, doing area damage.\n\nAttack : Only usable with melee weapons.
HephaÃ¤ron, Primordial of Industry, forged "Gaavanir,The First Hammer" to shatter bones and will alike. Only dust and despair remain in its wake.
Electrocute your foes with bouncing lightning. Each bounce is weaker that the last.\n\nSpell : Only usable with staves or catalysts.

Beelmalik, the fallen Lord of Punishment, used to rule over the primal element of lightning. He kept a distinct taste for chaining attacks, symbol of his desire to capture and emprison his brethren Abanazar, Lord of Envy, and Etheliel, Lady of Vanity.
Ice agglomerates above your enemies. After a short delay, it crashes upon them for huge damage.\n\nSpell : Only usable with staves or catalysts.
Etheliel, the fallen Lady of Vanity sheds deadly frozen tears whenever she is confronted with the world's decay. Ruthless sorcerers learned to leverage her sorrow into chilling death.
After a delay, hurls an ice shard in a line.\n\nSpell : Only usable with staves or catalysts.

Etheliel, the fallen Lady of Vanity, despises the use of ice as vulgar projectiles. The victims get impaled in atrocious ways which she cannot condone: they should be frozen instantly. Unfortunately few sorcerers actually care about these considerations.
An ice nova emanates from you and freezes your enemies.\n\nSpell : Only usable with staves or catalysts.
Etheliel, the fallen Lady of Vanity, wants to cover the world in ice to preserve it. Freezing foes and friends alike to trap their beauty, forever.
Channel a beam of Aether in front of you, damaging your foes.\n\nSpell : Only usable with staves or catalysts.

Anulai-Tai, the fallen Duke of Time is not nicknamed "The last Morrow" for no reason, channeling that much of his pure Aether energy always constitutes a danger to the fabric of time, and even moreso to those standing into it.
Summons a giant spear and leap down on your enemies, damaging them.\n\nAttack : Only usable with a melee weapon.
HephaÃ¤ron, the Maestre of industry forged "Ishmir, The First Spear" to teach men to work together on the battlefield. True warriors however will use this versatile weapon with lethal efficiency.
Bless an area around you with the light of dawn, it heals over time while standing in it.
AnathÃ«a, Lady of Dawn, can bring her light in the darkest dephts, warming the heart of those fighting the perils of the night. Brothers of Dawn are ever thankful of her protection.
Summon an imposing bow and launch several piercing arrows at once.\n\nAttack : Only usable with bows and pistols.
HephaÃ¤ron, the Maestre of Industry, forged "Krearion, The First Bow" by merging the power of a tidal wave and the accuracy of a lightning strike.
BaÃ¤pheth, Fallen Archduke of War, one of the nine shadows of the world, is the father of all warriors. Channeling his power grants the ferocity needed to survive a battlefield.

Krearion was forged with the ability to soak up the surrounding static energy and release it as sheer force whenever unleashing arrow volleys. The energy generated by the projectiles create a virtuous loop that allows a faster recharge of its attacks.

Abanazaar, once Primordial of fire, ravaged a continent seeking for his love interest, his envy was consuming and melting everything as the ground itself would twirl and turn into lava in his wake.\n\nWhile HephaÃ¤ron was his enemy, he was no fighter but an opportunist. He got to work, installing a forge near the melting continent and shaping its burning metals into superdense flaming arrowheads meant to feed the mouth of Krearion.
Adds a slowing effect in the area.

The wonders of innovation. Serrating arrowheads allowed for an alternative to flesh-penetration: should the projectile fail to pierce, it could now tear and peel the flesh of its victim. While it might not be lethal, warriors with shredded leg-muscles see their mobility reduced to an agonizing crawl, and at that point, they are as good as dead.
All the damage is now dealt directly, but reduced overall damage.

Scholars and logisticians have theorized that the impact of sustained fire on a specific battlefield area has gigantic disminishing returns in terms of efficiency. Accuracy and restraint allows for a more strategical approach that saves a considerable amount of ressources for roughly similar results.

Sarisel, the Primordial of Purity used Omeagram as an option to dispatch greater amounts of foes, littering the floor with the heads and limbs of those that were to be sanctified. While the weapon's blades were usually covered in gore, the deathbringer would however always remain untouched by the filth of the world.
The projectile now does a circle based on the cursor's location.

When Abanazaar, once Primordial of fire, crossed an ocean to meet with his love interest, it created a gigantic cyclone made of scorching steam. It is said that to tame the cyclone, HephaÃ¤ron started forging Omeagram inside of it to funnel its power into it.

After a while, every assassin learn to know and cherish each dent in his blade, every stripe, even the scent of its metal covered in fresh blood. A bond is forged between the killer and his lethal companion. This link will have the wielder manipulate his gear without having to think about it, like an extension of himself. This is what it takes to manipulate Omeagram to its full potential.

The edges of Omeagram were keened with such precision that HephaÃ¤ron boasted its ability to go through matter if thrown with enough might. While no-one questionned the terrifying sharpness of the blades, there was still no voluntary to test the claim with its own body.

When HephaÃ¤ron forged Gaavanir, he lended this dreaded weapon to BaÃ¤pheth, once Primordial of Ambition, to boast his own achievement. He wielded it with such power that craters and volcanos still serve as memories of the lands he scarred.

Trial and error is a mortal concern: Primordials define what is and what isn't, there is no room for improvements when things are absolute. Which explains HephaÃ¤ron's distress when BaÃ¤pheth prompted him to improve Gaavanir's design with a better balance of the handle.

When he finished the second design of Gaavanir, HephaÃ¤ron took the opportunity to improve even further the concussion on impact. There was no way he would let BaÃ¤pheth be the final word on how to improve the first hammer.
Improved critical chance on stunned enemies.

Gaavanir slumbers in the Armory of creation. It's very existence inspired the concept of battlehammers to craftsmen and blacksmiths around the world. Ever since, battlefields have been littered with broken skulls and crushed rib cages.

At its glory days, the Upheaval-Tribunal was a mythic structure that used to be permanently caught in freezing blizzards, thundering storms, and flowing lava. Now, only Beelmalik remains in its halls. With the embodiment of lightning as its magistrate, its judgements have never been so swift and numerous.

Reduced damage loss on each bounce.

Beelmalik's concept of Justice is rather approximative. Time does not wash away the sins, deeds are absolute and context superfluous which makes mercy absent from considerations. The result is that punishment takes a central place in his every judgement.

Beelmalik used to form the same entity with Abanazar and Etheliel. They were the Primordial of Change, ruling over the Upheaval-Tribunal. Ever since they splitted, Beelmalik has been obssessed with chasing and assimilating his brethren to be whole again.

As twisted and obsessive as Beelmalik can be, he still counts as a "Conciliator": a fallen trying to repair his past deeds against creation. His path to redemption may lead him to capture his two fallen brethren, Abanazar and Etheliel, and merge to become once again the Primordial of Change.

Etheliel has always been plagued by this thought: all beings aspire to live, but the very fact of living is a self-corrupting endeavour. Beautiful creatures wither and die, ideals become crooked and betray themselves, ideas are forgotten and lost to the ages. Everything is distorted by time.

Those who want to make a pact with Etheliel go through a disturbing ceremony known as the "Crystal salvation". The aspirant inoculates himself a dose of poison called 'Withering Roses" inside his forearm. As the first symptoms appear: black petals on the skin, the cultist has to stop the venom by freezing his arm forever or face an agonizing death.

Together, Abanazar, Beelmalik, and her used to be the Primordial of Change. But she is the one that stirred the first seeds of individualism deep within the Primordial's psychÃ«, inciting her brethren to develop their own will. Her plan was so successful that the master-being crumbled under the weight of its own egos, splitting into three entities.
Longer creation delay but increased damage.

While no-one knows precisely where to find Etheliel, myths tell the story of a freezing wail among the tall mountains that link the three continents of Wolcen. An echo so strong that it seems to mourn creation itself.

Tricking the fallen of Vanity into making her believe that you are a gateway for her will is a dangerous endeavour: A group of her cultists known as the Diamond Legion hunts down and capture usurpers, afflicting them with a frozen eternal torment.

å½¼å¥³ã®æå¿ã«ããªããå¥ãå£ã ã¨ä¿¡ãããããããèæ ã®å ç¥ãé¨ãã®ã¯å±éºãªåªåã§ããããã¤ã¤ã¢ã³ãé¨éã¨ãã¦ç¥ããã¦ããå½¼å¥³ã®å´æèéå£ããå¼·å¥ªèãç©ãæãããåã¦ã¤ãæ°¸é ã®è¦çã§è¦ãããã ããã

According to Etheliel, there's nothing as biting as the realization of a lost prime, a zenith that belongs in the past and from which things will only ever go downhill. That feelings alone can pierce the heart, wreck the mind, and lacerate willpower. The edges of her icicles are shaped by that omnipotent feeling.
Foes killed by Arctic Spear explode in shards, damaging nearby enemies.

Etheliel is not just hateful against the usurpers of her freezing powers, she becomes absolutely frenzied when she confronts sorcerers that dare to summon her powers to shred and tear apart the beauty of creation. Ironically, dreadful destructive blizzards spread around her when she loses control and exact her vengeance.
Longer creation delay but increased damage.

Ezaneal, fallen Lord of Trickery, seduced Etheliel to funnel her powers into an experimental device known as the Planetcracker. A siege weapon so powerful that it could hurl entire comets at its foes. Upon realizing she was being manipulated, she destroyed the Planetcracker and their cults have been at war ever since. Yet, the experiment proved that with enough power one could literally fire comets at his foes.

The ice of the lady of Vanity has lost its natural purity since she became a Fallen. Now it is filled with sadness, remorse, and a lethal determination to spread over the world. Woe to the fools that would mistake her unholy touch with the natural colds of winter.

Hidden temples of Etheliel are haunting sights: their chilling halls display all types of frozen creatures that were brought there for 'immortality' by cultists. In order to obtain her favors, the cultists have unholy rituals at the heart of the temple where they freeze captured young and beautiful people as sacrifice.

Etheliel knows generosity when it comes to sharing her power with mortals: she sees sorcerers and cultists as mere pawns serving her great ambition whenever they summon her cold embrace. Everytime her frost touches the world, she moves one step closer to her ultimate victory. In a way, ignorant sorcerers are just as dangerous as malignant cultists.

To freeze their abducted tributes while in their prime beauty, cultists of Etheliel are not allowed to harm them. But worst than that, tributes must not feel fear, wrath or anguish during the sacrifice ritual: these emotions distort the human face which would result in a refused offering from their mistress.

The fallen of Infinity has the power to reap and sever the bond between matter and time, leaving everything in his wake in a standstill state with no beginning nor end. His dominion over time is absolute just like his will to reach all things that move and bring them a motionless rest.

The cult of Infinity is a very dangerous one, their deadliest agents known as "Time Devourers", have specialized into isolating a foe from its normal bond to time, before discharging a tremendous amount of Aether unto the target. It accelerates its biorythm so much that a mortal will grow old and die by the end of the channeling.
Gradually increased damage over time while channeling.

Motionlessness is a key element in the training of Anulai-Tai's cultists. The flow of time brings movement and movement brings destruction which should be prevented. To obtain his favors, they must learn immuability, reducing their metabolism to a crawl and losing track of the flow of time, no beginning, no end just a blurry sense of being.

In his madness, Anulai-Tai feels all the movements in the world and their destructive nature, like a fuzzy haze of blasphemy toward creation. His gaze puncture through that haze, piercing space and flesh, seeking for targets to single out and lay to rest.
Has a chance to stun on impact.

Deep within every creature there is the terror to stop existing. A buried feeling so strong that it can turn the fiercest foe into a simple prey. The shadow of a warrior diving on its enemies while holding Ishmir can awaken that primal conditionnement, shattering the fighting spirit of those about to die.

The sight of the spear's head piercing the flesh, the painful deathrattle of the skewered foe, its warm blood splattering the face of the impaler: madmen and berserkers thirst for these grim omens to create an unstoppable momentum of destruction.

HephaÃ¤ron forged magical neck rings for AnathÃ«a the Lady of Dawn. With them, her voice of pure light was imbued and became the Searing Song, allowing her to pierce the darkest nights. In return she gave him a single bright smile, which he immortalized by infusing its sacred shimmer into the blade of Ishmir.

BaÃ¤pheth, former Primordial of ambition had a single training session with Ishmir. In the midst of the fight, he threw it with such power that it fended an entire mountain. Since then, the earth itself reacts strongly whenever The First Spear touches the ground.
Area is now centered at cursor location.

The Brotherhood of Dawn worships AnathÃ«a. Even after being chased from the Kingdom of Alia once the United Republic of Mankind took over, they stayed true to their oaths and remained powerful knights shielding innocents from the terrors of the night.

The lady of Dawn is a benevolent Primordial who defends creation against the fallens. She rules over the concepts of Dawn, Hope, Truth, and Rebirth. She tries to shepherd mankind into her humbling lights while giving it the powers to survive against supernatural invasions.
Grants an armor bonus while inside the area.

Facing the injustice and perils of the world, some have lost faith in AnathÃ«a's existence on the claim that through recorded history, she never intervened herself to help creation. Some Brothers chose to fight-off this faithlessness by becoming "Hierophants of the Searing Song", battlepriests that teach her prayers and blessings to shield mankind from evil.
Grants sacred damage to Attacks while standing in the area.

Among Brothers of Dawn, a squire may try to become an Aurora Knight. On the way to this iconic title, an aspirant will have to take five oaths. There is a period of observation inbetween oaths to make sure the candidate is up to the engagement. Upon taking the last, a great deed to defend mankind must be accomplished, only then, will the title be his.

At first, Krearion inspired craftsmen around the four realms to build portable ballistas. Only the strongest men could draw the bow, and the manoeuverabilty of these archers was questionnable at best. Since then, a lighter more 'human' version was conceived: the longbow.

Before Krearion got stored into the Armory of creation, no men ever had the idea of swift ranged weapons that could rain mayhem on your foes. Since then, successive crushing defeats taught generals to stop relying on heavy cavalry to win their war.
Reduced amount of projectiles but increased damage.

Sarisel, Primordial of Purity and born hunter of evil, saw potential in that new weapon: a tool to bring down his foes with minimal effort. The way he wields it obeys its own logic: shoot to kill. Each arrow must count and reap a reward or the power spent to shoot it is a lost expense.

BaÃ¤pheth used to be the Primordial of Ambition before falling and taking the aspect of War. He was the first to understand the consequences of bowmen on the battlefield. Arrow volleys do not have to kill, the constant despair and mayhem they spread in enemy ranks is where a battle is won.
Grants rage per enemy hit by the shout and improved rage per hit for the duration of the skill.

Conquerors have one simple rule to limit casualties during battle: always give an escape route to the opposing army. If their moral is broken, the soldiers will grasp at every straw they can to get out of the chaos, their ranks will break as they run for the exit.\n\nBut what happens to those that gave up on survival altogether? True berserkers cannot be broken, controlled, or contained. The raging chaos they bring in their wake is the terror of every would-be strategist.
Enemies hit by the shout gain stacks of "weakened".

During the great war of the Primordials, BaÃ¤pheth engaged and fought against AnathÃ«a, the Lady of Dawn. The First Warrior's prowess could not be match in battle, but AnathÃ«a's raw power was so great he could not overpower her.\n\nIn the end, BaÃ¤pheth had the upper hand and wounded AnathÃ«a, some of her lights escaped her body uncontrolably, engulfing and searing BaÃ¤pheth in and out. Both were considerably weakened by the experience and unable to give the final blow.
Grants bonus armor per enemy hit by the shout.

Before becoming the fallen of War, BaÃ¤pheth used to be the Primordial of Ambition. Part of his ubris came from his willingness to embody the perfect warrior. To be a figure that others could look-up to at the darkest time. When others would consider breaking the line, he would not relent and command them to stand with him. Most would mistake his quest for glory for an heroÃ¯sm that never was.
Stun foes in a small radius.

BaÃ¤pheth is a born conqueror. But far from being a mindless battlebeast, he turned to be a patient strategist. He understands that battles are won way before soldiers ever set foot on the field. The successful belligerant breaks the will of his foes long before breaking their bones.
Damage bonus for each successively hit target: %1
Charge(s) gained when the skill is equipped: %1
Charge(s) gained when the skill is used: %1
Charge(s) gained when the skill hits: %1

Critical Damage bonus per charge gained: %2%

Critical Damage bonus per charge lost: %2%
Bleeding stack(s) inflicted for each charge lost: %2
Additional projectile for each lost charge: %2

Critical Damage bonus per charge spent: %2%
Bleeding stack(s) inflicted for each charge spent: %2
Additional projectile for each charge spent: %1
Cooldown duration when spending the last charge: %2
Ammunitions affect only Ranged shots and spells that explicitely state so
This spell is affected by skills and effects that usually affect Ranged shots (ammunitions, bouncing, etc.)
This spell is affected by Ammunition skills
Enemy's health threshold for increased Critical Chance modifier: %1
You can move through enemies while cloaked
This spell affects you as well as enemies
Requires a valid target to be cast
Pull yourself towards enemies by maintaining the spell key
This spell will affect all your attacks with Ranged Weapons as soons as it is equipped in your skills bar without requiring any further action
Number of summoned creatures is increased by %1
Maximum number of simultaneous summons is increased by %1
Angle between projectiles is increased by %1
Angle between projectiles is reduced by %1
